image.altText: Empty liquor bottles and cans lay in the dry Todd River.

items.synopsis: The NT opposition says compulsory alcohol treatment should be reintroduced in Alice Springs as a long-term measure to address chronic alcoholism, but support workers say mandating treatment is a poor motivator for change.

title.children: Interim alcohol restrictions are about to expire in Alice Springs, so what's next for the embattled town?

image.altText: A woman works inside a cannabis shop.

items.synopsis: As discussion ramps up to relax cannabis laws across Australia, experts say it's important to look at what's happened in Thailand one year since marijuana was decriminalised.

title.children: 'Sorry, we're stoned': What can Australia learn from Thailand a year after weed became legal?

image.altText: A band of four people poses against a beige backdrop.

items.synopsis: Ten Australian albums might feature in the top-50 ARIA chart each week a decade ago, but now there's more likely just one or two. Industry insiders say it's a crisis for local artists.

title.children: This Australian band topped the ARIA charts, but it's part of a dying breed

image.altText: A man with a towel on his head floats blissfully in a Japanese hot spring

items.synopsis: There's nothing quite like soaking in one of Japan's natural hot springs. But resort owners are refusing to share the geothermal energy reserves that could transform this resource-poor nation.

title.children: Japan sits on top of a huge reserve of clean, cheap power. Some call it 'devil energy'

image.altText: Photo of sandstone building with canon at front. Tree in left corner with concrete in it.

items.synopsis: Rotting and riddled with wasps, in the 1980s an ailing blue gum at Anglesea Barracks was filled with concrete to stabilise it. Almost four decades on the old tree still stands, is still alive, and the concrete is barely visible.

title.children: Rotting away from the inside out, this blue gum was filled with concrete. Four decades later it's stronger than ever

image.altText: A woman holding a baby looks out a hole in the wall

items.synopsis: Israeli forces have concluded their largest-scale military operation in the occupied West Bank city of Jenin in decades. But many say this raid could be the beginning of a major escalation.

title.children: Israel launched a huge raid on a Palestinian refugee camp. Here's why it could change everything

image.altText: A smiling man sitting with a group of people in grey jumpsuits and white helmets in the background

items.synopsis: Xavier Doerr was injured during 'horrendous' conditions while attempting to break several records circumnavigating Australia.

title.children: Sailor rescued after 'terrifying' ordeal in rough ocean waters during record attempt

image.altText: A young man in blue shirt, black jeans, brown boots,glasses, rides on a bicycle past a white building.

items.synopsis: By the end of the year, the Bureau of Meteorology will have automated every weather station in regional mainland Australia. Except this one, in the heart of the outback.

title.children: Just how isolated this weather station is takes some explaining. But that's not what makes it unique

image.altText: Protesters stage a rally against the Japanese government's decision to release treated radioactive water.

items.synopsis: Worries about the safety of Japan's planned release of Fukushima's wastewater is sparking protests and boycotts in China and South Korea, but experts say the anxiety is not based in scientific facts.

title.children: Anxiety grows across Asia Pacific nations ahead of planned Fukushima wastewater release

image.altText: time lapse image of satellites orbiting over a astronomy station

items.synopsis: Scientists, looking deep into space, have long voiced their concerns that satellites are encroaching on their ability to study the cosmos.

title.children: Scientists prove Elon Musk's Starlink satellites are interfering with ability to study the cosmos

image.altText: Australia batter Travis Head launches a ball awkwardly during a Test at Headingley.

items.synopsis: Australia sets England 251 to win after rain ruined most of day three of the third Ashes Test in Leeds. Here's the five things you missed overnight.

title.children: Five quick hits — Rain hits Headingley … and Head hits sixes on day three

image.altText: Pat Cummins purses his lips and throws the ball to himself

items.synopsis: Australia can retain the Ashes on day four at Headingley, but will need a memorable performance to do so. Still, in a series so tight, a better opportunity may never come.

title.children: A day that seemed destined to be rained out, has instead set up another grandstand Ashes finish

image.altText: Jane Bari in the garden

items.synopsis: A hearty garden and empty freezer have helped Jane Bari and her husband go from having just $100 to their names to a life free of debt, and something that could help other older Australians out of poverty.

title.children: How one couple changed their lifestyle to live below their means

image.altText: A white woman wearing a purple jacket standing in front of the Coburn Hotel.

items.synopsis: Slim Dusty once played there and it was bustling pre-pandemic, but now the doors are shut at Cockburn's pub with locals fearing the tiny town will die without its business.

title.children: Plenty of beer but no-one to run 130yo pub as town fights to 'keep place alive'

image.altText: Mark Cavendish covers his eyes

items.synopsis: On the cusp of Tour de France history, British rider Mark Cavendish crashed out of the race on stage eight.

title.children: Heartbreak for Tour de France legend as record remains intact

image.altText: Man holding his hand sore lower back

items.synopsis: Over centuries, posture has been linked to chronic back pain. Research has debunked this for decades, so why do we still believe it?

title.children: How pseudoscience and racism influenced the idea of 'good posture'

image.altText: A man and a woman riding a motorcycle with a sidecar.

items.synopsis: When researching the previous owner of his 1976 kombi van, Craig Allen unearthed an unlikely tale of two post-war migrants who dedicated half a century to preserving Indigenous culture.

title.children: Stephen and Helen evaded the Nazis and the Soviets, then set off to preserve Australia's fading cultures

image.altText: A building next to a tree at Launceston General Hospital.

items.synopsis: A scathing coroner's report on Friday about the Launceston General Hospital is the latest in a string of adverse coronial findings against the hospital in recent years.

title.children: This hospital has had eight findings against it in six years. Here’s what coroners have found is going wrong

image.altText: A woman of colour, a black woman and a white woman stand backstage at a fashion event wearing brightly-coloured dresses.

items.synopsis: Gender-neutral, inclusive and sustainably produced fashion is at the heart of Gary Bigeni’s latest collection, but it’s taken the better part of two decades for him to find his feet.

title.children: This designer custom-makes clothes from his mum's backyard in Western Sydney — and they're divine

image.altText: Two men stand in front of a mound of dirt.

items.synopsis: Collins says many First Nations people would be able to relate to the characters in Limbo, a film about the disappearance of a young woman from an outback town.

title.children: 'Like a muffled scream': Rob Collins on making outback noir film Limbo

image.altText: Megan Rapinoe on a soccer field, spreading her arms wide in celebration

items.synopsis: The two-time world cup winner and Olympic medallist announced her retirement days before heading to New Zealand for the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup.

title.children: Megan Rapinoe announces imminent retirement from soccer

image.altText: A cap-wearing Australian tennis player brings his racquet back behind his head, watching the ball, ready for a backhand return.

items.synopsis: Australia will not have a singles player in the second week at Wimbledon for the first time since 2018 after Chris O'Connell was beaten by Chris Eubanks.

title.children: Aussie Wimbledon singles challenge ends with Chris O'Connell exit

image.altText: Jilkminggan community

items.synopsis: Northern Territory Police have charged a man with murder after a woman died in the remote community of Jilkminggan on Thursday night.

title.children: Man charged with murder over the alleged stabbing death of his partner in remote community

image.altText: a young woman smiling and looking at the camera

items.synopsis: No topic is off bounds for Summer Williams and her biographer who is part of a new program offered to children hospitals across Sydney allowing kids to chronicle their life.

title.children: 'My amazing life': The project giving children in palliative care the chance to tell their own story

image.altText: A young boy in a red baseball cap and a woman sit at a table filling in forms.

items.synopsis: Indigenous residents in the Kimberley region of WA, including some who never received a birth certificate, are being empowered with recognised identification.

title.children: Outback residents to 'take some control' with new community-led IDs

image.altText: A top football executive stands at a railing with a flower in her hair and Sydney Opera House in the background.

items.synopsis: The journey to the summit that the FIFA Women's World Cup now occupies has either been incredibly fast, or terribly slow, depending on who you talk to.

title.children: FIFA's game changer — from police raids to records, growth and reform

image.altText: A young woman singing on a stage.

items.synopsis: There may be a frenzy over tickets for Taylor Swift, but for smaller fish in the music scene like Perth band Joan & The Giants, the post-pandemic landscape is tough — possibly tougher than it has ever been.

title.children: Musicians investing house deposits, taking on second jobs to survive as touring costs soar

image.altText: Two McLaren F1 drivers smile as they stand on a stage with microphones during a talk for fans at the British grand prix.

items.synopsis: F1 championship leader Max Verstappen takes another pole position at Silverstone, but the McLaren team comes up big with hometown hero Lando Norris and Australia's Oscar Piastri to start second and third at the British Grand Prix.

title.children: Max Verstappen takes pole for British F1 grand prix, Aussie Oscar Piastri third

image.altText: Photo of brown substances in a box

items.synopsis: Two Australian agribusinesses have come up with highly unusual ways to help poor farmers in Laos.

title.children: Australian agribusinesses utilise innovative strategies to empower farmers in Laos

image.altText: Zelenskyy carrying blue and yellow flowers kneeling over steps and placing red candle infront of sign

items.synopsis: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy hails the country's soldiers from the Black Sea island where guards once told a Russian warship "go f*** yourself".

title.children: Zelenskyy marks 500 days of war against Russia from famous Snake Island

image.altText: A women's soccer team from the 1970s wearing white shirts with red shorts and green socks

items.synopsis: St George Budapest's women's team was the first to represent Australia at an international tournament.

title.children: Meet St George Budapest: The club team that kickstarted the Matildas

image.altText: A woman looking at an old glucose machine for diabetes

items.synopsis: In the 1970s, Stanley Clark wanted to stop his little girl's suffering. So, he built the world's first portable blood glucose monitoring machine in a New South Wales suburban backyard.

title.children: Stanley Clark's sweetest invention was made for his daughter. It's since helped millions of diabetes sufferers
